page.title: 07Ecology
page.content: Birds, such as greylag and pinkfoot geese, brambling finches, field-fare and redwing thrushes return from their breeding grounds in Greenland and Iceland to spend only winter months here. Owing to the disappearance of mature Scots Pine, caipercaillie have became almost extinct in places where formerly they thrived. Sightings of Kingfishers are now extremely rare events also. However, crossbill numbers seem to be increasing and the colourful green woodpeckers have moved north, establishing themselves in our woodlands alongside greater spotted woodpeckers. The severe winter of 1983/84 took a heavy toll of the long tailed tit and wren populations.
